body: Nobody knows a man better than his ex-wife. So Moe Prager's ex-wife, Carmella, is wise to this veteran private eye, accepting the fact that no matter how many times he marries, his first love will always be Brooklyn. ''When you die, they should just bury you right here, under the boardwalk,'' she tells him in HURT MACHINE (Tyrus, $24.95; paper,
title: CRIME; Last Exits in Brooklyn

author: Twitter: @mwilsonnyt
body: The locker that nobody wants to open is on the seventh floor of a massive police building on East 20th Street. Turn left out of the elevator, then walk down a hall and through a cluttered computer training classroom, to a door in the rear marked Ceremonial Unit. Another left into a little dead-end hall, and there it is, the last locker on the left,
title: CRIME SCENE; For Fallen Officers, a Simple Symbol of Grief

body: THERE are still places where 18th Avenue, as it runs through Bensonhurst, looks like the Italian-American stronghold that it once was. Spaced at intervals along the street, also known as Cristoforo Colombo Boulevard, are businesses like Gino's Focacceria, the Bari Pork Store, S.A.S. Italian Records and the Villabate Alba bakery. But just as in
title: LIVING IN | BENSONHURST, BROOKLYN; Accessible, From All 4 Corners of the World

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Brooklyn Historical Society: 'Civil Rights in Brooklyn: Stories of Struggle and Protest' (Sunday) A discussion, with archivists and audience participation, on the impact in Brooklyn of the civil rights movement, in celebration of its 50th anniversary. 128 Pierrepont Street, near Clinton Street, Brooklyn Heights, (718)
title: Spare Times

body: Women -- can't live with 'em, can't live without 'em. Can't call them 924 times in one month during a fight. Can't plot to plant drugs and guns on their new boyfriends. Can't look for hit men to assassinate their new boyfriends. These and other life lessons crashed down around Salah Youssef, 38, whose journey from lovesick paramour to defendant in
title: CRIME SCENE; What's a Love-Struck Pimp to Do?

body: John C. Liu, the New York City comptroller, has vaulted into the top tier of political figures in the city, building a formidable fund-raising machine that has quickly established him as a contender to succeed Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. Mr. Liu recently announced, with great fanfare, that he had taken in $1 million in the first six months of the
title: Doubts Raised On Donations To Comptroller

body: ''HOPE you enjoyed the Labor Day weekend. Did you know there are only 109 shopping days left until Christmas?'' O.K., perhaps the pitches retailers intend to deliver, beginning this week, will not be that blunt. But there is no underestimating their anxiety as they face a holiday shopping season hobbled by a struggling economy, a gyrating stock
title: ADVERTISING; The Season for Optimism

body: For the first time in nearly two decades, students in New York City's public middle and high schools will be required to take sex-education classes beginning this school year, using a curriculum that includes lessons on how to use a condom and the appropriate age for sexual activity. The new mandate is part of a broader strategy the Bloomberg
title: Sex Education Again a Must In City Schools

body: Lorraine Johnson says she remembers the garbage trucks that lined up near her housing project on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, to unload trash at a marine sanitation station on the East River. They made noise, spewed diesel fumes, attracted rats and smelled bad -- ''like dead bodies,'' she said. ''I have nightmares just thinking that there's a
title: In Fight Against Trash Station, Upper East Side Cites Injustice

body: IF the last couple of years are any indication, about 50,000 fans will show up at Belmont Park on Saturday to watch the running of the 143rd Belmont Stakes, the premier race on the New York State calendar. Belmont can handle a crowd twice the size, but it's an off year. No horse will run for the Triple Crown, since Animal Kingdom, the long-shot
title: Belmont Awaits Its Annual Return to Glory

body: New Yorkers angry about trash on their sidewalks tend to propose the obvious solutions: more litter baskets at more corners, more frequent collection, harsher fines for violators. But in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, the neighborhood has come up with a novel -- and counterintuitive -- tactic. It is to get rid of the litter baskets. On three busy commercial
title: Fighting Litter in Brooklyn By Getting Rid of the Litter Baskets

body: ''We demand a recount,'' declared Assemblyman Rory I. Lancman, a Democrat from Queens. The Brooklyn borough president, Marty Markowitz, pronounced himself ''flabbergasted.'' ''The numbers are dead wrong,'' said Senator Charles E. Schumer, ''and it makes you wonder if the Census Bureau is living on a different planet.'' After learning that the
title: New York City's Claim of a Census Undercount May Be Justified, Canvassing Finds

body: ON a sunny day, with a cool breeze blowing off the water and people sitting at sidewalk tables sipping tea from small glasses, Emmons Avenue in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, could almost be in Istanbul -- or even in the Ukrainian port city of Odessa. Which may explain why so many Turkish and Ukrainian immigrants have made themselves at home among the
title: LIVING IN | SHEEPSHEAD BAY, BROOKLYN; Calm and Clamor, in Equal Measure

body: In 1999, when Our Lady of Perpetual Help High School closed, Margaret Doria and Anita Dente feared it would be the end of them. For 33 years, Ms. Dente, the school's Italian teacher, and Ms. Doria, an English teacher, had worked together, car-pooled together to the school in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, finished each other's sentences. ''We couldn't
title: ON EDUCATION; Joined at Hip, and, to Some Pupils, by a Hyphen

body: SHOULD we take our tea with pits or without? The Ukrainian affection for sour cherries and tea, the server explained as he set down a pot, can be indulged by spooning the first into the second, or by nibbling the one and sipping the other. There's also a custom, he later noted, of drinking tea through a sugar cube clenched between the teeth. This
title: $25 AND UNDER; Cheery, With a Side Of Sour Cherries

body: Pins clattered to a soundtrack of the Drifters and the Temptations as if it were a half-century ago when Maple Lanes first opened, only without the clouds of smoke. Men wearing gold chains with bowling pin pendants hugged and kissed as if they had not seen one another in years, instead of the Wednesday before, while women unpacked their bowling
title: BOROUGH PARK JOURNAL; In Brooklyn, Bowlers Enjoy A Haven While It's Still Around

body: Let's begin with the mystery of the hidden bathroom. It's the summer of 2008. A young couple decides to buy an 800-square-foot apartment in a new condo building on the gentrifying outer edge of a fashionable Brooklyn neighborhood. The buyers go to close on the place, and as they're signing away half a million dollars, the building's developer,
title: The Supersizer of Brooklyn

body: THEY are well-heeled warriors. These squash players do battle behind thick glass at the courts of the Yale Club, in Midtown Manhattan, backed by a soundtrack of roars and grunts and lunging bodies slamming against walls. On a recent weekday, one of the liveliest contests was on Court 2, where an older man was running a much younger player ragged
title: SWEAT; 92 Years Old, And Still Ruling The Squash Court
